description: A historic 13th-century Georgian Orthodox church perched dramatically on a cliff overlooking the Mtkvari River, where King Vakhtang I Gorgasali is believed to have founded Tbilisi in the 5th century. The Church of the Nativity of the Mother of God stands as one of Tbilisi's most iconic landmarks, accompanied by an imposing equestrian statue of the city's founder and offering breathtaking panoramic views of Old Town.
highlights: 13th-century cross-cupola church built between 1278-1289 AD under King Demetrius II, featuring traditional Georgian architectural style with three projecting apses and cross-in-square design
Dramatic cliffside location on Metekhi Cliff, built to look like a natural continuation of the rock formation, visible from many points across the city
Sacred burial site of St. Shushanik the Martyr (5th century) and martyrdom place of St. Abo of Tiflis (8th century), patron saint of Tbilisi
Majestic 13-meter bronze equestrian statue of King Vakhtang I Gorgasali created by sculptor Elguja Amashukeli, unveiled in 1967
Unparalleled panoramic views of Old Tbilisi including Narikala Fortress, Abanotubani baths district, Peace Bridge, and Rike Park
Historic Metekhi neighborhood, one of the earliest inhabited areas of Tbilisi, with name meaning 'area around the palace' dating to 12th century
Site of royal palace and fortress from 5th century that served as King Vakhtang's residence according to oral tradition
Traditional Georgian rock carvings and decorations on exterior, particularly well-preserved on eastern facade with three apses
Survived Stalin era when Lavrenti Beria intended to destroy it but met opposition from Georgian intellectuals, notably painter Dimitri Shevardnadze who was executed for his defiance
Former prison complex (1819-1934) where Stalin and other revolutionaries were once imprisoned, adding layers to the site's historical significance
tips: Best time to visit: Early morning or late afternoon during golden hour (sunrise/sunset) for optimal lighting and fewer crowds, especially beautiful when illuminated in the evening
Photography equipment: Bring wide-angle lens for expansive courtyard views and standard zoom for architectural details; flash photography not permitted inside during services
Dress code: Dress modestly as active place of worship - cover shoulders and knees out of respect
Duration: Allow 30 minutes to explore the church, courtyard, and small Abo chapel beneath the main structure
Free admission: No entrance fee to visit the church and grounds
Access: Connected to Old Tbilisi via Metekhi Bridge (King Gorgasali Bridge) which offers scenic river views
Nearby attractions: Walk to Abanotubani sulfur baths district, Narikala Fortress, and Old Town - all within close proximity
Best photo spots: Courtyard for panoramic Old Town views, around King Vakhtang statue for dramatic shots, and from across the river for full cliffside perspective
Visit weekday mornings for serene experience with minimal crowds
Combine with walking tour of Old Town as Metekhi is perfectly positioned to start or end exploration of historic Tbilisi
vibe: Sacred and majestic. Standing on this ancient cliff where Tbilisi was born, you feel the weight of 1,500 years of history beneath your feet. The church rises like a natural extension of the rock, while the bronze king on horseback gazes eternally over the city he founded. It's a place where legend and history intertwine - from the founding myth of the falcon and pheasant falling into hot springs, to the tragic tale of 100,000 martyrs who refused to step on icons, to the artist who sacrificed his life to save this building from demolition. The panoramic views are simply breathtaking, especially during golden hour when Old Tbilisi glows across the river. Despite its dramatic history including use as a prison where revolutionaries were held, the site maintains a serene spiritual atmosphere. The neighborhood itself feels like stepping back through centuries, where every stone tells a story of kings, saints, and the resilient Georgian spirit. It's both a photographer's paradise and a pilgrim's destination, offering moments of contemplation alongside stunning vistas.
